dublinCore.dc:title: 117 HR 1437 EAH: Further Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, 2023
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

engrossed-amendment-form.current-chamber: In the House of Representatives, U. S.,

section.text: That the House agree to the amendment of the Senate to the bill (H.R. 1437) entitled An Act to amend the Weather Research and Forecasting Innovation Act of 2017 to direct the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to provide comprehensive and regularly updated Federal precipitation information, and for other purposes., with the following

amendment-instruction.text: In lieu of the matter proposed to be inserted by the Senate, insert the following:

section.header: Short title
section.text: This Act may be cited as the Further Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, 2023.

section.header: Table of Contents
section.text: The table of contents of this Act is as follows:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 4. Payment to Widows and Heirs of Deceased Members of Congress.

section.header: References
section.text: Except as expressly provided otherwise, any reference to this Act contained in any division of this Act shall be treated as referring only to the provisions of that division.

section.header: Payment to Widows and Heirs of Deceased Members of Congress
section.text: There is hereby appropriated for fiscal year 2023, out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, for payment to Colette Wallace McEachin, beneficiary of Aston Donald McEachin, late a Representative from the Commonwealth of Virginia, $174,000.
The Continuing Appropriations Act, 2023 (division A of Public Law 117–180) is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking the date specified in section 106(3) and inserting December 23, 2022;
by adding after section 157 the following new section:

section.text: During the period covered by this Act, section 227(a) of the Federal Cybersecurity Enhancement Act of 2015 (6 U.S.C. 1525) shall not apply.
This division may be cited as the Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2023.

section.header: Extension of FCC Auction Authority
section.text: Section 309(j)(11) of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 309(j)(11)) is amended by striking December 16, 2022 and inserting December 23, 2022.

section.header: Extension of Authorization for Special Assessment for Domestic Trafficking Victims’ Fund
section.text: Section 3014(a) of title 18, United States Code, is amended, in the matter preceding paragraph (1), by striking December 16, 2022 and inserting December 23, 2022.

section.header: United States Parole Commission Extension

subsection.text: This section may be cited as the United States Parole Commission Further Extension Act of 2022.

subsection.header: Amendment of Sentencing Reform Act of 1984
subsection.text: For purposes of section 235(b) of the Sentencing Reform Act of 1984 (18 U.S.C. 3551 note; Public Law 98–473; 98 Stat. 2032), as such section relates to chapter 311 of title 18, United States Code, and the United States Parole Commission, each reference in such section to 35 years or 35-year period shall be deemed a reference to 35 years and 53 days or 35-year and 53-day period, respectively.

section.header: Extension of Commodity Futures Trading Commission Customer Protection Fund Expenses Account
section.text: Section 1(b) of Public Law 117–25 (135 Stat. 297), as amended by section 104 of division C of the Continuing Appropriations and Ukraine Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2023 is amended by striking December 16, 2022 each place it appears and inserting December 23, 2022.

section.header: Budgetary Effects

subsection.text: The budgetary effects of this division and each succeeding division shall not be entered on either PAYGO scorecard maintained pursuant to section 4(d) of the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010.
The budgetary effects of this division and each succeeding division shall not be entered on any PAYGO scorecard maintained for purposes of section 4106 of H. Con. Res. 71 (115th Congress).

Notwithstanding Rule 3 of the Budget Scorekeeping Guidelines set forth in the joint explanatory statement of the committee of conference accompanying Conference Report 105–217 and section 250(c)(8) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985, the budgetary effects of this division and each succeeding division shall not be estimated—

paragraph.text: for purposes of section 251 of such Act;
for purposes of an allocation to the Committee on Appropriations pursuant to section 302(a) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974; and
for purposes of paragraph (4)(C) of section 3 of the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010 as being included in an appropriation Act.

section.header: Extension of increased inpatient hospital payment adjustment for certain low-volume hospitals

subsection.text: Section 1886(d)(12) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395ww(d)(12)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (B), in the matter preceding clause (i), by striking December 17, 2022 and inserting December 24, 2022;
in subparagraph (C)(i)—

subparagraph.text: in the matter preceding subclause (I), by striking December 16, 2022 and inserting December 23, 2022;
in subclause (III), by striking December 16, 2022' and inserting December 23, 2022; and
in subclause (IV), by striking December 17, 2022 and inserting December 24, 2022; and

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (D)—

subparagraph.text: in the matter preceding clause (i), by striking December 16, 2022' and inserting December 23, 2022; and
in clause (ii), by striking December 16, 2022' and inserting December 23, 2022.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Secretary of Health and Human Services may implement the provisions of, including the amendments made by, this section by program instruction or otherwise.

section.header: Extension of the Medicare-Dependent Hospital program

subsection.text: Section 1886(d)(5)(G) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395ww(d)(5)(G)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in clause (i), by striking December 17, 2022 and inserting December 24, 2022; and
in clause (ii)(II), by striking December 17, 2022 and inserting December 24, 2022.
Section 1886(b)(3)(D) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395ww(b)(3)(D)) is amended—

subparagraph.text: in the matter preceding clause (i), by striking December 17, 2022 and inserting December 24, 2022; and
in clause (iv), by striking December 16, 2022, and inserting December 23, 2022.

paragraph.text: Section 13501(e)(2) of the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 (42 U.S.C. 1395ww note) is amended by striking December 16, 2022 and inserting December 23, 2022.

section.header: Extension of increased FMAPs under Medicaid for the territories
section.text: Section 1905(ff) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1396d(ff)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (2), by striking December 16, 2022 and inserting December 23, 2022; and
in paragraph (3), by striking December 16, 2022 and inserting December 23, 2022.

section.header: Medicare Improvement Fund
section.text: Section 1898(b)(1) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395iii(b)(1)) is amended by striking $7,308,000,000 and inserting $7,278,000,000.

section.header: Extension of maternal, infant, and early childhood home visiting programs
section.text: Activities authorized by section 511 of the Social Security Act shall continue through December 23, 2022, and out of any money in the Treasury of the United States not otherwise appropriated, there is hereby appropriated for such purpose an amount equal to the pro rata portion of the amount appropriated for such activities for fiscal year 2022.

section.header: Extension of child and family services programs
section.text: Activities authorized by part B of title IV of the Social Security Act shall continue through December 23, 2022, in the manner authorized for fiscal year 2022, and out of any money in the Treasury of the United States not otherwise appropriated, there are hereby appropriated such sums as may be necessary for such purpose.

section.header: Reauthorization of the critical path public-private partnership
section.text: Section 566(f) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 360bbb–5(f)) is amended by striking $1,265,753 for the period beginning on October 1, 2022 and ending on December 16, 2022 and inserting $1,380,822 for the period beginning on October 1, 2022 and ending on December 23, 2022.

section.header: Reauthorization of the best pharmaceuticals for children program
section.text: Section 409I(d)(1) of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 284m(d)(1)) is amended by striking $5,273,973 for the period beginning on October 1, 2022 and ending on December 16, 2022 and inserting $5,753,425 for the period beginning on October 1, 2022 and ending on December 23, 2022.

section.header: Reauthorization of the humanitarian device exemption incentive
section.text: Section 520(m)(6)(A)(iv) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 360j(m)(6)(A)(iv)) is amended by striking December 17, 2022 and inserting December 24, 2022.

section.header: Reauthorization of the pediatric device consortia program
section.text: Section 305(e) of the Pediatric Medical Device Safety and Improvement Act of 2007 (Public Law 110–85; 42 U.S.C. 282 note) is amended by striking $1,107,534 for the period beginning on October 1, 2022, and ending on December 16, 2022 and inserting $1,610,959 for the period beginning on October 1, 2022 and ending on December 23, 2022.

section.header: Reauthorization of provision pertaining to drugs containing single enantiomers
section.text: Section 505(u)(4) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 355(u)(4)) is amended by striking December 17, 2022 and inserting December 24, 2022.

section.header: Reauthorization of certain device inspections
section.text: Section 704(g)(11) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 374(g)(11)) is amended by striking December 17, 2022 and inserting December 24, 2022.

section.header: Reauthorization of orphan drug grants
section.text: Section 5(c) of the Orphan Drug Act (21 U.S.C. 360ee(c)) is amended by striking $6,328,767 for the period beginning on October 1, 2022, and ending on December 16, 2022 and inserting $6,904,110 for the period beginning on October 1, 2022 and ending on December 23, 2022.

section.header: Reauthorization of reporting requirements related to pending generic drug applications and priority review applications
section.text: Section 807 of the FDA Reauthorization Act of 2017 (Public Law 115–52) is amended, in the matter preceding paragraph (1), by striking December 16, 2022 and inserting December 23, 2022.

section.header: Reauthorization of third-party review program
section.text: Section 523(c) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 360m(c)) is amended by striking December 17, 2022 and inserting December 24, 2022.

section.header: Extension of Moratorium
section.text: Section 424(a) of title IV of division G of Public Law 113–76 is amended by striking December 16, 2022 and inserting December 24, 2022.

section.header: Short title
section.text: This Act may be cited as the Providing Research and Estimates of Changes In Precipitation Act or the PRECIP Act.

section.header: Amendment to the Weather Research and Forecasting Innovation Act of 2017 relating to improving Federal precipitation information

subsection.text: The Weather Research and Forecasting Innovation Act of 2017 (15 U.S.C. 8501 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Study on precipitation estimation

subsection.text: Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of the PRECIP Act, the Administrator, in consultation with other Federal agencies as appropriate, shall seek to enter an agreement with the National Academies—

paragraph.text: to conduct a study on the state of practice and research needs for precipitation estimation, including probable maximum precipitation estimation; and

to submit, not later than 24 months after the date on which such agreement is finalized, to the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate, and make publicly available on a website, a report on the results of the study under paragraph (1).

subsection.text: The report under subsection (a) shall include the following:

paragraph.text: An examination of the current state of practice for precipitation estimation at scales appropriate for decisionmaker needs, and rationale for further evolution of this field.
An evaluation of best practices for precipitation estimation that are based on the best-available science, include considerations of non-stationarity, and can be utilized by the user community.
A framework for—

subparagraph.text: the development of a National Guidance Document for estimating extreme precipitation in future conditions; and
evaluation of the strengths and challenges of the full spectrum of approaches, including for probable maximum precipitation studies.

paragraph.text: A description of existing research needs in the field of precipitation estimation in order to modernize current methodologies and consider non-stationarity.

A description of in-situ, airborne, and space-based observation requirements, that could enhance precipitation estimation and development of models, including an examination of the use of geographic information systems and geospatial technology for integration, analysis, and visualization of precipitation data.
A recommended plan for a Federal research and development program, including specifications for costs, timeframes, and responsible agencies for addressing identified research needs.
An analysis of the respective roles in precipitation estimation of various Federal agencies, academia, State, tribal, territorial, and local governments, and other public and private stakeholders.
Recommendations for data management to promote long-term needs such as enabling retrospective analyses and data discoverability, interoperability, and reuse.
Recommendations for how data and services from the entire enterprise can be best leveraged by the Federal Government.
A description of non-Federal precipitation data, its accessibility by the Federal Government, and ways for National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to improve or expand such datasets.

subsection.text: There is authorized $1,500,000 to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to carry out this study.

section.header: Improving probable maximum precipitation estimates

subsection.text: Not later than 90 days after the date on which the National Academies makes public the report under section 601, the Administrator, in consideration of the report recommendations, shall consult with relevant partners, including users of the data, on the development of a plan to—

paragraph.text: not later than 6 years after the completion of such report and not less than every 10 years thereafter, update probable maximum precipitation estimates for the United States, such that each update considers non-stationarity;
coordinate with partners to conduct research in the field of extreme precipitation estimation, in accordance with the research needs identified in such report;

make publicly available, in a searchable, interoperable format, all probable maximum precipitation studies developed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration that the Administrator has the legal right to redistribute and deemed to be at an appropriate state of development on an internet website of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration; and

ensure all probable maximum precipitation estimate data, products, and supporting documentation and metadata developed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration are preserved, curated, and served by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, as appropriate.

subsection.header: National Guidance Document for the Development of Probable Maximum Precipitation Estimates
subsection.text: The Administrator, in collaboration with Federal agencies, State, territorial, Tribal and local governments, academia, and other partners the Administrator deems appropriate, shall develop a National Guidance Document that—

paragraph.text: provides best practices that can be followed by Federal and State regulatory agencies, private meteorological consultants, and other users that perform probable maximum precipitation studies;
considers the recommendations provided in the National Academies study under section 601;
facilitates review of probable maximum precipitation studies by regulatory agencies; and
provides confidence in regional and site-specific probable maximum precipitation estimates.

subsection.text: Not later than 2 years after the date on which the National Academies makes public the report under section 601, the Administrator shall make publicly available the National Guidance Document under subsection (b) on an internet website of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

The Administrator shall update the National Guidance Document not less than once every 10 years after the publication of the National Guidance Document under subsection (c) and publish such updates in accordance with such subsection.

section.header: Definitions
section.text: In this title:

paragraph.text: The term Administrator means the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere and Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
The term National Academies means the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine.

The term United States means, collectively, each State of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, American Samoa, Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the Virgin Islands of the United States, and any other territory or possession of the United States.

subsection.text: Section 1(b) of the Weather Research and Forecasting Innovation Act of 2017 (15 U.S.C. 8501 note) is amended in the table of contents by adding at the end the following:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 602. Improving probable maximum precipitation estimates.
